div.ab: The large canon, which is for great batteries, usually weighs fifty-five or lx quintals. At the breech it carries the thickness of b two bullets &l a third of one bullet. At the front, it carries ba the thickness of one bullet & two thirds. It is thirteen or fourteen pans in length. But they are very troublesome to drive. The head-on battery, to accomplish its task quickly is & batter with great force ranges at a hundred fifty paces & at two hundred. And It is true that one batters well from three or 4 hundred paces, but it is necessary to give it more powder. Its common load is of xx lb of powder, its bullet of 40 lb.. One needs xxv horses to drag it. When one drags it farther than its usual range, one puts in a half linstock of canon powder more. A cannon can be shot 80 or a hundred shots per day, but one needs to refresh it every time after one has shot te nine or ten shots, if the battery is continuously used. For if there is a break, it is not necessary to refresh it as often. For two quintals of copper, or two quintals & a half if it is for large cannons, one puts one quintal of metal. The metal is composed at the beginning of eight lb. of tin for one quintal of rosette, and also for big bells one only puts six lb. of fine tin for one quintal of rosette, to give it a bigger voice. For the more tin there is, the clearer the sound is. Its For gun founding, if one provides the material & charcoal as one usually does for masters do not have the means, one gives x to xii lb. per quintal. And for the mat when the master provides everything, one gives him 40 lb. per quintal for large pieces such as cannons, according to the King's ordinance, and l lb. for small pieces. T For the more material there is, the more profit the master has of it. One founds another kind of fowlers of xxx quintals which are longer than the others, and easily eight pans long, & they are for battering defenses & casemates s by placing them par trenchees at night the edge of the ditch.

On each side of the breech's opening they give the thickness of half a ball. And then they also add on each side the third part of a ball.
Ain one gives it two linstocks of cannon powder for its charge, & one & a half of arquebus powder, & the same for the others.

The composition for cannons from France is one quintal of metal for two of rosette. But those of Toulouse & Poncet put iii of rosette & one of metal.
The rosette for re-melting is more profitable than cauldrons, which turn entirely into filth.

left-bottom
Old pieces are composed of almost de dem as much one as of the other, namely one part of rosette & one of metal. One recognises this composition with a burin. For its substance is found to be sour & the particle taken from the burin is found to be mixed with yellow & white.
